Hi, I'm Craig, and this is Crash Course Government
and Politics. And today, we're gonna get personal.

8.text:
Not personal in the sense that I'm gonna tell you
I'm a bed wetter cause I'm not...gonna tell you that.

12.text:
We're gonna talk about people's personal political
views and where they come from. This is what

15.text:
political scientists sometimes call Political
Socialization.

18.text:
But before we get into the forces that help
create our political outlooks, we should probably

21.text:
define what political ideologies look like
in America.

33.text:
In America, there are a number of ways
people characterize themselves politically.

36.text:
Typically, they identify with a political party, although
as we'll see when we talk more about parties,

40.text: this has become less likely over time.

42.text:
And although there's a lot of overlap between
political party and political ideology, there's

48.text:
But there is 100% overlap between my fist
and this eagle's beak! Politics.

53.text:
So, now I should probably say what I mean
by political ideology. Basically, I'm talking

57.text:
about whether you identify as liberal or conservative
or libertarian or socialist or anarchist or

62.text:
nihilist or craigist - people who just love
me. I'm one of those.

69.text:
You're probably familiar with the idea that
liberals are on the left, and conservatives

72.text:
are on the right. And this can be a helpful shorthand,
but what political views do these terms represent?

76.text:
Let's go to the Clone Zone! What? The Clone
Zone - it's right here now? I'll just...I'll

81.text: leave then. This way? I'll go this way.

83.text:
Taking a cue from anti-federalists, American
conservatives believe that a large government poses

88.text:
a threat to individual liberty, and we prefer our national 
government to be as small as possible. (Scoffs)

93.text:
We have this in common with libertarians.
There are some basic functions like national

96.text:
defense that government can best take care
of. But especially since the New Deal, our

100.text:
government has taken on too much. What government
we need is best handled by states and localities.

105.text:
For the most part, American conservatives
believe in the free market and that it will

108.text:
provide the greatest economic opportunity
and benefit to the greatest number of people.

113.text:
American conservatives usually support a strong
defense. This is one place where we generally don't

117.text:
think spending should be cut. Most other programs,
the things that fall under discretionary spending,

122.text:
can and should be left up to the private sector. And 
this will allow the government to reduce its spending.

126.text:
Lower spending, in turn, will mean lower taxes.
Ahh, delicious lower taxes.

131.text:
This means that we don't like flag burning,
and we favor prayer in schools because these

134.text:
reflect traditional religious and patriotic
values.

137.text:
Just like the eagle. I love the eagle. You're
my friend. (Kisses eagle)

141.text:
Many conservatives, as strong adherents
to religious faiths, are against abortion.

144.text:
But I'd say there's a greater diversity in conservative
views on social issues than on economic ones.

149.text:
The social sphere is where we differ significantly
from our libertarian friends who don't see

153.text:
any role for government in people's personal
lives. This means that libertarians often

157.text:
support things like marijuana legalization that
more traditional conservatives do not support.

161.text:
If there's one value that American conservatives
privilege above others, it's liberty. America

164.text:
is a country of freedom, and in most cases, government
is more of a threat to liberty than a protector of it.

169.text:
And I'm out. (Kisses hand and touches eagle's
head)

172.text:
Not bad conservative clone.
But bad, here's why.

175.text:
Sometimes liberals in the U.S. are called
New Deal Liberals because the policies that we

179.text:
support grew out of the New Deal. And lately, a number
of us are trying to re-brand ourselves as progressives.

183.text:
Although this is a little tricky given that, historically,
progressives and liberals aren't the same thing.

187.text:
In general, American liberals believe that
government can help solve problems, and a

191.text:
bigger government, like a glorious soaring
eagle can solve bigger problems and more of them.

198.text:
We support government intervention in the
economy, both in the form of regulations and

202.text:
higher taxes, especially when that intervention
benefits historically marginalized groups

206.text: like minorities, women, and the poor.

207.text:
We like to the government step in on behalf
of consumers and to protect the environment

211.text:
because in general, we don't trust that the
free market will be fair to everyone.

214.text:
We know that protection of the environment, aiding
the poor, and expanding civil liberties all cost money,

218.text:
so we usually favor a progressive tax system
with higher taxes on the wealthy and corporations.

223.text:
Although not all American liberals are anti-business,
as a rule we don't have a lot of faith that big

227.text:
businesses have the average American's best interest
at heart, and so we prefer to see them regulated.

231.text:
Although we still see national defense as
important, most American liberals feel that

235.text:
the country spends more than enough on the
military and that the defense budget should

238.text:
be cut, leaving more money for necessary social
programs.

241.text:
In the debate over guns or butter, we like
butter. Although we're also fine with the

244.text: government telling us not to eat so much of it.

246.text:
If conservatives value liberty, we liberals
cherish equality as their primary political

250.text:
virtue, and we see government as a necessary agent in
promoting equality. (Kisses hand and pats eagle's head)

255.text: We're equals, me and that eagle.

257.text:
Thanks clones. So, for the most part, this
is what most American liberals and conservatives

261.text:
believe, and these are the basic foundations
upon which they build their political opinions.

264.text:
But where do they come from? (Punches eagle
and eagle tumbles to the floor)

267.text:
Political scientists sometimes refer to the
process by which individuals establish their

270.text:
personal political ideologies as political
socialization. And they have identified four

274.text:
main agents that contribute to our political
identities.

277.text: Let's go to the Thought Bubble!

278.text:
The first and most important source of our
politics is family. This makes a lot of sense

282.text:
since kids either want to emulate their parents
or reject their ideas. And parents are usually

286.text:
the first people that express political opinions
to kids.

288.text:
As I suggested, family can influence your
political outlook in negative and positive

292.text:
ways. If you respect your parents and admire
them, it's likely you will adopt their political ideology.

296.text:
On the other hand, adopting an opposing political
view can be a form of rebellion.

300.text:
Still, for the most part, liberal parents
breed liberal children, and conservative parents

305.text:
The second major influence on political ideology
is social groups, which in this case, refer

309.text:
to one's race, gender, religion, or ethnicity.
Obviously, these are generalizations, but

313.text:
certain groups tend to fall predictably into
liberal or conservative camps.

316.text:
African Americans and Jewish people are among
the most liberal Americans while white Catholics

320.text:
tend to be conservative. Latinos are an interesting
case because many identify as Catholic, but

324.text: they tend to be more liberal politically.

326.text:
One of the reasons that many use to explain
why African Americans and Latinos tend to be

329.text:
liberals is that these groups are disproportionately poor
and receive a significant share of government benefits.

334.text:
To this way of thinking, economic self interest
is a prime determiner of where one stands

339.text:
politically, and it also explains why white
conservatives, especially those who are wealthy,

342.text:
favor policies of lower taxes and less government
intervention.

345.text:
One problem with this purely self interested
view of political ideology though is that

349.text:
there is a large number of low income, low
wealth white voters who also do or would gain

352.text:
from more government benefits. But they tend
to be conservative.

355.text:
In other words, be careful when you try to define
a person's politics by looking at their bank account.

359.text:
Gender also tends to be statistically significant
in terms of political ideology. The gender

363.text:
gap refers to the fact that women tend to be
more liberal overall than men. This is especially

367.text:
true on the issue of national defense where they
tend to favor spending reductions rather than increases.

371.text:
Thanks Thought Bubble. The third agent of
political socialization in the U.S. is education,

375.text: namely the primary and secondary school system.

378.text:
This is the most formal way that our political
views are shaped since almost all American

381.text:
students take at least one year of American
history, and many states require courses in civics.

385.text:
In these courses, students learn about political
values like liberty and equality and may come

389.text:
to align themselves with a liberal or conservative
view.

391.text:
And maybe you're watching me in one of these
classes right now...

395.text:
Conservatives tend to think that American
schools and textbooks skew towards a liberal

399.text:
outlook, but this might be because most public
school teachers are members of unions, and

403.text:
teachers' union membership correlates highly
with a liberal viewpoint.

406.text:
Whether or not most teachers and textbooks
are liberal, it's a bit of a leap to assume

409.text:
that most students will automatically adopt
the ideology of their teachers.

412.text:
Education does relate to political ideology
in at least one measurable way though.

416.text:
In that the higher the level of education one
attains, the more likely one is to profess

419.text:
liberal views on issues such as women's rights
or abortion.

422.text:
On the other hand, higher education levels also
correlate with more conservative views on issues

426.text:
like government support of national health insurance or
affirmative action programs to help African Americans.

430.text:
So, as with many things we look at, things
aren't so clear cut, and it's important to

434.text: have some kind of data to back up our generalizations.

436.text:
One final agent of political socialization
are the political conditions one lives through.

440.text:
Example - if you grew up during the Great
Depression and saw FDR's New Deal programs

444.text:
benefit you and your family, it's likely that you'd
develop and maintain pro-government, liberal views.

448.text:
If you came of age during the Reagan era,
when popular politicians were singing the

451.text:
praises of self-reliance and calling government
the problem rather than the solution, it's

455.text:
likely that you'd develop conservative political
views.

457.text:
It remains to be seen whether people who form
their political identities during the Great

460.text:
Recession will be liberal or conservative.
But don't worry - pollsters are busy trying to figure it out.

465.text:
So there you have a very broad outline of
what the words conservative and liberal mean

468.text:
in American politics and some of the factors
that turn people into liberals or conservatives.

472.text:
More than probably anything I've said in this
series, these are generalizations that you

475.text:
need to look at critically. This doesn't mean
that if you find someone or if you are someone

478.text:
who doesn't fit either description 100%, that
we're completely wrong, only that political

483.text: ideologies are complex and change over time.

485.text:
But we need to understand the outlines of
these generalities because they get used all

488.text:
the time in our discussions of American politics. In fact,
it would be hard to talk about politics without them.
